title: Are the British religious people? - Quora

response.answer_text: You will be unable to find two surveys that provide similar statistics. Christianity is confirmed as the main religion with statistics ranging anywhere from 50-63%. Within these figures The Church of England is largest Christian faith, followed by Protestant, Catholic and smaller Christian societies. 2011 show 59.5% Christianity. Muslims make up 5% of religion. Hinduism represents approximately 1.3% Sikhism follows at 0.7%, Judaism and Buddhism both at 0.4% The 2011 census figures show 25.7% have no religion and 7.2% instated. The census indicated a 12% reduction in Christianity from 2001 census and it is expected the downward % is still continuing so current estimates are around 50%. The wide range of figures concerning Christianity are still unreliable and totally misrepresent the actual figure. A poll carried out by the Guardian in 2006 provided question ‘which religion do you yourself belong to ‘ with 64% stating Christianity and 26% stating ‘none' Another question from the same survey asked ‘are you religious’ with 63% saying ‘no' and 33% answering ‘yes'. This is supported by decade by decade fall in Church attendances ever since the Victorian age. This is put down to advancements within scientific research giving better factually based understandings of the universe thus diminishing the scope of the supernatural and the role for a God. As a consequence there is a very large grey area whereby a high percentage choose Christianity as their upbringing religion although they are not actively involved or may not have any beliefs. I would place myself within this category. I was brought up Christian and went to C of E schools. I think at the age of 10/11 years old we were taught about the Old Testament during lessons and I also began to read it at home. I did not get very far through Genesis. It started OK but as soon as it introduced more and more people all over the age of 900 it seemed too far fetched for me and 10 years old. Additionally I was very interested in Astronomy and read many books on the subject at school. With significant technological advancements during the 80s I resumed with astronomical reading material but now books for adults moving on to complex topics of quantum mechanics, superstring theory, particle physics etc. My beliefs are now scientifically based. Having said that I believe 100% there was a person named Jesus and very likely the named disciples surrounding him. I think in the Biblical era stories were like Chinese whispers and became more exaggerated from village to village and finally into the miracles that the Bible depicts. I do not know if I qualify to be a Christian or even religious because I do not believe all of the teachings? Am I classified 33% C of E or completely written off as a non believer?

Officially, less than 50% of British people identify as religious. Of those who still do, most only attend church for weddings and funerals. Back in the 70s when religious fighting between Catholics and Protestants kept religion in the news, churches were often standing room only. But since the end of the “troubles,” religion has nose dived to today where churches are lucky to fill the front pew. Which just goes to prove the success of any religion relies on violence and hate.

UK is multi-national, multi-cultural and multi-faith. Generally it is a secular state, but individually there are many different religions practised. Some are ardent followers, some only on religious festivals and others don’t follow any religion e.g. Atheists and agnostics.

In Britain religion has more to do with the class system and being seen by and with the right people, Many friends of mine would ignore religion the whole year except for christenings, funerals and marriages. Then at Christmas time they would dress up and go to the church or better still the local cathedral. You will also see churches packed if its to be televised.

It depends on which part of Britain you are talking about: The Scots and welsh tend to be more religious, having more of a non establishment and non conformist past. The English less so especially in urban areas. That doesn't mean most of them, apart from a few vocal atheists, don't subscribe to Christianity but they don't see it as relevant to day to day life much.
No, not all that many of them anyway. They believe in football (soccer), cricket, pubs, fish n chips, a nice curry, and a swim in the sea.
Depends how you define ‘religious’. Belief in god or persistence of tradition. Tradition here is changing rapidly…belief is just as strong as it ever was.
Frankly no, in 2018 Pew research put the number who consider religion as very important as 10% in the UK. People in Europe and East Asia say religion is not very important to them
Like Lots Of Countries Not All Yes Our Country Has A Official Religion With The Queen Being The Head Of The Church Of England But We Do Have Religious Freedom Like Most Countries
